ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How database systems work from a rigorous level. You will learn about how databases handle concurrency, queries, isolation, durability, etc.

We learned about the relational model (tables, tuples, attributes, superkeys, primary keys, foreign keys, entity-relationship diagrams, etc.). We learned about measuring the efficiency of search queries in certain models (e.g. calculating the number of disk seeks required for a query). We learned about B+ trees. We learned about transactions and scheduling.
learned literally nothing please don't take this class.
I learned about SQL and basic DBMS concepts.
SQL, database architecture, indexing, storage.
A little SQL, relational algebra
good
database concepts and application
Databases
The basics of SQL and Database design. We learned how to create and manage both large and small relationships of information.

By taking this graduate database course, you will have gained a strong foundation in database concepts and technologies and developed skills in data modeling, SQL, database design and optimization, data integrity and security, and data analytics. You will learn how to design and implement effective database schemas, write SQL queries to retrieve and manipulate data, optimize database performance through indexing and other techniques, and use databases to support data analysis tasks such as aggregating and summarizing data, performing statistical analysis, and generating reports. There's also a very enjoyable final project at the end.

In addition, if you plan to take this class make sure you do not take it with the TA Tong Cheng. Tong is a very arrogant and rude TA who consistently belittles and disrespects students in the class. His lack of patience and poor communication skills often make it difficult for students to understand the material and he frequently refuses to provide additional assistance or clarification. His unprofessional behavior has caused me great frustration within the class and has had a negative impact on the overall learning experience. It is important for TAs to be respectful and supportive of their students, but Tong consistently falls short in this regard.
Database management.
sql, database management
knowledge about SQL databases
database design
I learned a bit about databases and their nuances, although a lot less than I expected.
Database Systems
Db
Some basic knowledge on database.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course ended up being taught entirely on zoom, while it was supposed to be in person after the first two weeks. I do not blame professor Avi because he shared that his health kept him from going to the class, but it felt like the class was doomed from that point on. The class on zoom was disorganized and the virtual communication was poor during class and outside of class. I think that most of the TAs were really carrying this course in terms of creating/grading assignments, even the two exams.
Course was taught virtually which was disengaging. Course material was very dense and full of a ton of concepts that really needed their own dedicated lectures.

The progression from one topic to the next was reasonable and well-paced. This was a strength of the course. The main weakness was the medium (Zoom). The course was listed as in-person and the expectation was that it would be. I understand that the transition to Zoom was due to a health issue, so this is outside of the Professor's control. Another weakness was that every assignment and exam was multiple-choice, and so no human feedback/grading occurred. The exception to this was our first homework assignment (the only non-multiple-choice work for this course this semester), and the first homework assignment went ungraded (everybody received 100/100).

The course is unstructured. The professor and the TAs are doing completely separate things. Wrong problems appeared on almost every quiz and homework, and it takes forever for the TAs to grade the HW or just simply release the auto-graded work.

The course was completely unhinged. We are in a post COVID world why are we still on zoom? The TAs were completely checked out and all of our assignments were graded on canvas (multiple choice). There was no one for help or guidance, despite reaching out multiple times on Ed there was no engagement. I learned nothing about databases. The assignments were very useless and a complete waste of time. And grades are pretty random too. This is a very low workload class but definitely is not a gut. It is like, here do 0 work the whole semester and then get a random grade. Very disappointed.
If possible, in-person lectures would be more engaging!

This course has some really useful information and content but the lectures were absolutely useless. The lectures consisted of Avi reading off of a powerpoint on Zoom the entire semester, even though classes have been in person for over a year now.
The weakness of this class is that the lectures are just reading text of the slides which is exactly what is in the textbook. Strengths is there is a lot of information that you can learn.

This class is super disorganized. The quizzes and exams constantly had typos, repeated questions, or just unfinished questions. The first homework was super complicated and touched on topics that we hadnt learned in class, and then they didnt even end up grading it and told us two months after turning it in that we all would get 100% on it. This class was also posted as an in-person class but it ended up being held on Zoom.
good

The weakness is definitely course organization. There was a lack of feedback from multiple psets and from the final project, and the class was online the entire semester. The only consistent aspect was taking quizzes with very ambiguous questions that were often removed because they had multiple or no right answers or were too difficult for the time limit. Strength is the pure information learned. Database understanding is a highly valuable skill in a multitude of real-world applications.

This class has many strengths, including a patient and enthusiastic professor who is dedicated to helping students understand the material and is always available to provide additional assistance and clarification. The slides are also amazingly detailed and make it very easy to study for the exams in this class. One weakness of this class is how open ended it is for the final project. You'll need to come up with an original independent database system and create a web app to host it. Since this class doesn't teach web development, you're completely on your own for this project. Also, another con is a TA named Tong who was rude and unresponsive. Avoid him. Overall, while the class has many strengths, the weakness of having an unresponsive TA can be detrimental to your experience.
Incredibly disorganized class, there seemed to be a main problem with lack of TA's compared to the class size and it showed.

Suitable for theoretical methods.
Weak for implementation.

Let me keep it a buck with you so you know what you're getting yourself into: the first problem set we were assigned, no one knew what we were doing and the content on the problem set was from Avi's textbook, a part of the chapter that we were supposed to cover ourselves as Avi did not go over it in class, I pull up to Office Hours having already worked on all of the problems and I just had a syntax question - I get to one of the TAs and explain to them the confusion I'm having and he deadass just tells me he didn't write the question and the TA that wrote the question wasn't there. Then we didn't get the grades back for that problem set well after our midterm. This course was just very poorly managed and not fun to attend.
Weakness is homeworks are multiple choice so you dont actually learn any SQL which was what i was seeking
should have more TAs
Relatively interesting material
tie the quizzes and assignment to contents in the class the more closely

The course has several weaknesses, in particular offering it on zoom is terrible for the students since there is no meaningful engagement possible when the professor is simply reading off the slides. Moreover, there is too little emphasis on SQL and database practice. I feel a very theoretical course on database is not a good "introduction" to the topic and is of little interest. On top of that, assignments are not helpful in learning and critically thinking about the material because they are all multiple choice. The grade is also split up into too many parts, no class needs to have quizzes + assignments + final project + midterm exam + final exam.
Already perfect
Lecture time

The contents are not very engaging or helpful.
For students who want to do research in this area, there should be some deeper and more interesting content.
For students who just want to learn some basic knowledge about database, SQL and related topics should be involved more, both in the lectures in the homework.
From this perspective, neither of these two kinds of students would benefit much from this class, so it's hard to see who are the targeted students.
The organization is also quite messy.
Professor did not answer questions clearly during the lectures and was more just reading the slides.
Also, I've seen classes with more students and the same amount of TFs, but they were much more organized than this course.
TFs do not answer questions very quickly: some academic questions, not administrative ones, are left open for weeks.
Homework was graded very slowly. In the end, everyone gets 100 for the only written homework.
It's also hard to see what TFs are doing. Perhaps they were coming up with homework questions, but that doesn't seem to take 5 TFs + the professor.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Not if it is taught in the same manner. In person may be better but the course just ended up being one of my least favorite at Yale because of how the semester went. I ended up with a good grade but I would not say that I am taking much away from this class in terms of skills I learned or experience gained.
Workload is on the lower side but the class is not that engaging. Would not recommend unless you just need the credit.

If the course is to be taught on Zoom, then I would not recommend it to another student. I would especially advise against taking this course if the state of assignments and exams (all multiple-choice) remains the same. There is also a corresponding lack of human feedback, when everything is multiple-choice. Meaningful feedback is important for engagement and learning.
No. This course is the worst course I've taken at Yale.
Definitely not don't take it.
No. Learn about DBMS elsewhere this course was not useful at all

I would not recommend this course in is current format. There is very little hands on learning and if you are not a visual learner this class is very hard. I ended up teaching myself everything through youtube videos. The homework's were assigned for us to learn things that were unable to be taught in the lecture due to time constraints rather than reinforce what we were learning in the class. I feel like I learned a lot of theory and can speak to core database concepts but I have no idea how to implement it.
No
yes, good course
If you want to take a CS major class that you won't think about very often, absolutely.

I would recommend this course to another student because it teaches a lot about advanced databases and is taught by an amazing and extremely talented professor and TA named Jane Lee who really went above and beyond. They are both very patient and enthusiastic, and are always willing to provide additional assistance and clarification. However, don't take the class with the TA named Tong Cheng at all costs. Do NOT take the class with him!!!!! Worst TA experience I have ever had. Sent multiple emails and he took over 2 MONTHS to reply. Completely unacceptable.
It's a pretty easy credit for a 400 level CS elective, but in terms of actually learning anything I wouldn't recommend this class.
Not unless you need a CS gut in a heavy course workload
yes
if you are interested in how to build efficient databases
yes basic level cs course
I would not recommend this class to anyone genuinely interested in learning databases and gain working knowledge about them.
Yes if they would like to know more about database
Yes

Definitely do not recommend it.
Please avoid this course if you truly want to learn something about database. I very much regret taking this course.
It's a waste of time, and I didn't learn much. 
I did homework and spent time watching the lecture and taking the exams, but none of them truly helped me learn what I want to learn.
The topics arrangement and organization in general are both quite messy.
If you want an easy A, however, this might be a good course. 
Not a lot to do, although still some. 
And homework and exams were arranged as if they do not care if you learn anything, but that also means they are graded very leniently.
To sum up: easy-A class but you can barely learn anything.
